skull.brief: Protects the brain and houses sensory organs.
skull.description: Composite axial skeleton structure formed from cranial and facial bones that encase the brain, support the airway and provide attachment points for the muscles of mastication and facial expression.
skull.innervation: Trigeminal nerve (sensory branches) and cranial nerve motor branches for mastication and facial muscles
skull.action: Protective bony vault for the brain; provides attachment for facial muscles
functions: Encases and protects the brain, cranial nerves and meninges
Houses special sense organs for vision, hearing, taste and smell
Provides anchorage for muscles of facial expression, mastication and speech
skull.bloodSupply: Branches of the external and internal carotid arteries, including the middle meningeal and superficial temporal vessels
examTips: Inspect for scalp lacerations, step deformities or cephalohaematoma after trauma
Look for cerebrospinal fluid leak (otorrhoea/rhinorrhoea) and periorbital ecchymosis in suspected basilar fractures
skull.imageCaption: Anterior skull view highlighting cranial sutures and fossae
skull.clinicalPearl: Basilar skull fractures may present with raccoon eyes or Battle's sign — inspect carefully.
clinicalPearls: Basilar skull fractures may present with raccoon eyes or Battle's sign — inspect carefully.
In trauma, palpate the zygomatic arch, maxilla and mandible for step deformities indicating mid-face fractures

Skull.brief: Protects the brain and houses sensory organs.
Skull.description: Composite axial skeleton structure formed from cranial and facial bones that encase the brain, support the airway and provide attachment points for the muscles of mastication and facial expression.
Skull.innervation: Trigeminal nerve (sensory branches) and cranial nerve motor branches for mastication and facial muscles
Skull.action: Protective bony vault for the brain; provides attachment for facial muscles
functions: Encases and protects the brain, cranial nerves and meninges
Houses special sense organs for vision, hearing, taste and smell
Provides anchorage for muscles of facial expression, mastication and speech
Skull.bloodSupply: Branches of the external and internal carotid arteries, including the middle meningeal and superficial temporal vessels
examTips: Inspect for scalp lacerations, step deformities or cephalohaematoma after trauma
Look for cerebrospinal fluid leak (otorrhoea/rhinorrhoea) and periorbital ecchymosis in suspected basilar fractures
Skull.imageCaption: Anterior skull view highlighting cranial sutures and fossae
Skull.clinicalPearl: Basilar skull fractures may present with raccoon eyes or Battle's sign — inspect carefully.
clinicalPearls: Basilar skull fractures may present with raccoon eyes or Battle's sign — inspect carefully.
In trauma, palpate the zygomatic arch, maxilla and mandible for step deformities indicating mid-face fractures

cranium.brief: Bony structure of the skull encasing the brain.
cranium.action: Protection of brain and intracranial structures
cranium.clinicalPearl: Basilar skull fractures may present with raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymosis) or Battle's sign (mastoid ecchymosis).

Cranium.brief: Bony structure of the skull encasing the brain.
Cranium.action: Protection of brain and intracranial structures
Cranium.clinicalPearl: Basilar skull fractures may present with raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymosis) or Battle's sign (mastoid ecchymosis).

mandible.brief: Lower jaw bone - largest and strongest facial bone.
mandible.origin: Forms from Meckel's cartilage during development
mandible.insertion: Articulates with temporal bone at temporomandibular joint (TMJ)
mandible.innervation: Inferior alveolar nerve (branch of mandibular division of trigeminal)
mandible.clinicalPearl: Mandibular fractures are the second most common facial fracture after nasal bones. Check for malocclusion, step deformity, and numbness in the lower lip.

Mandible.brief: Lower jaw bone - largest and strongest facial bone.
Mandible.origin: Forms from Meckel's cartilage during development
Mandible.insertion: Articulates with temporal bone at temporomandibular joint (TMJ)
Mandible.innervation: Inferior alveolar nerve (branch of mandibular division of trigeminal)
Mandible.clinicalPearl: Mandibular fractures are the second most common facial fracture after nasal bones. Check for malocclusion, step deformity, and numbness in the lower lip.

jaw.brief: Lower jaw bone - largest and strongest facial bone.
jaw.origin: Forms from Meckel's cartilage during development
jaw.insertion: Articulates with temporal bone at temporomandibular joint (TMJ)
jaw.innervation: Inferior alveolar nerve (branch of mandibular division of trigeminal)
jaw.clinicalPearl: Mandibular fractures are the second most common facial fracture after nasal bones. Check for malocclusion, step deformity, and numbness in the lower lip.

clavicle.brief: S-shaped bone connecting the shoulder to the axial skeleton.
clavicle.origin: Medial end articulates with manubrium of sternum
clavicle.insertion: Lateral end articulates with acromion of scapula
clavicle.action: Strut connecting upper limb to trunk, protects neurovascular bundle
clavicle.clinicalPearl: Most commonly fractured bone in children. Falls on outstretched hand (FOOSH) cause fractures typically at the middle third. Check for tenting of skin and neurovascular compromise.

scapula.brief: Flat triangular bone on the posterior thorax.
scapula.origin: Spine, acromion, and coracoid process provide attachment sites
scapula.insertion: Glenoid fossa articulates with humeral head
scapula.innervation: Dorsal scapular nerve, suprascapular nerve, axillary nerve
scapula.action: Provides attachment for shoulder muscles, enables arm movement
scapula.clinicalPearl: Scapular winging indicates serratus anterior weakness (long thoracic nerve injury). Check by having patient push against a wall.

spine.brief: Supports the body and protects the spinal cord.
spine.innervation: Spinal nerves (31 pairs) exiting between vertebrae
spine.action: Axial support, load bearing, movement and neural protection
spine.clinicalPearl: Loss of vertebral height or step deformity on exam suggests compression fractures — check imaging.

ribs.brief: Form the rib cage to protect thoracic organs.
ribs.insertion: Anteriorly to the sternum (true ribs) or via costal cartilage (false ribs)
ribs.innervation: Intercostal nerves (ventral rami of thoracic spinal nerves)
ribs.action: Protection of thoracic organs and assistance with respiration
ribs.clinicalPearl: Flail chest (multiple adjacent rib fractures) can cause paradoxical chest wall motion; consider analgesia and respiratory support.

sternum.brief: Midline breastbone connecting the rib cage.
sternum.origin: Manubrium, body, xiphoid process (components of the sternum)
sternum.action: Central anchor for ribs and thoracic muscles
sternum.clinicalPearl: Sternal fractures commonly result from high-energy anterior chest trauma; evaluate for cardiac contusion if suspected.

humerus.description: Long bone of the upper limb forming the glenohumeral joint proximally and the elbow joint distally. Provides a lever for powerful shoulder and elbow musculature and transmits force from hand to trunk.
humerus.origin: Proximal articulations with the scapula (glenohumeral joint)
humerus.insertion: Distally with radius and ulna at the elbow
humerus.action: Upper limb movement and force transmission
functions: Serves as the attachment site for rotator cuff, deltoid and arm musculature
Transmits compressive and torsional forces between the hand, forearm and shoulder girdle
Maintains the humeral head within the glenoid via ligamentous and muscular support
humerus.bloodSupply: Anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries and branches of the profunda brachii
examTips: Assess axillary nerve function (shoulder abduction, regimental badge sensation) after proximal fractures
Check radial nerve motor function (wrist extension, finger extension) for spiral groove injuries
humerus.clinicalPearl: Proximal humeral fractures are common in older adults after a fall; check axillary nerve function (shoulder abduction) and vascular status.
clinicalPearls: Proximal humeral fractures are common in older adults after a fall; check axillary nerve function (shoulder abduction) and vascular status.
Mid-shaft fractures risk radial nerve palsy causing wrist drop; document motor power and dorsal hand sensation

radius.description: Shorter lateral bone of the forearm that rotates around the ulna to allow pronation and supination while transmitting axial load to the wrist.
radius.origin: Proximally articulates with humerus and ulna
radius.insertion: Distally forms part of the wrist (carpal bones)
radius.innervation: Radial and median nerve contributions to surrounding muscles
radius.action: Forearm rotation and load transmission to wrist
functions: Acts as the mobile bone of the forearm permitting pronation and supination
Transmits force from the hand to the elbow via the radiocarpal joint
Provides insertion for biceps brachii and supinator to generate rotation
radius.bloodSupply: Radial artery and recurrent branches around the elbow
examTips: Check distal radioulnar joint stability and grip strength after distal radius fractures
Assess median nerve function (thumb opposition, sensation over index finger) after volar plating
radius.clinicalPearl: Distal radius (Colles') fractures often occur from FOOSH; check for dinner-fork deformity.
clinicalPearls: Distal radius (Colles') fractures often occur from FOOSH; check for dinner-fork deformity.
Smith fractures (volar displacement) can cause median nerve compression — monitor for carpal tunnel symptoms

ulna.brief: Medial forearm bone important for elbow stability.
ulna.description: Longer medial forearm bone that forms the trochlear notch of the elbow and provides longitudinal stability to the forearm, acting as the hinge axis for flexion and extension.
ulna.insertion: Distally forms part of wrist articulation with radius
ulna.innervation: Ulnar nerve supplies intrinsic hand muscles and sensation medially
ulna.action: Forms hinge of elbow and stabilises forearm
functions: Acts as the stable forearm bone during pronation and supination
Provides insertion for triceps brachii at the olecranon to extend the elbow
Maintains alignment of the humeroulnar joint during weight bearing
ulna.bloodSupply: Ulnar artery and posterior interosseous branches
examTips: Palpate the olecranon, radial head and medial epicondyle to assess the elbow triangle after injury
Check ulnar nerve sensation over the little finger and intrinsic hand strength (finger abduction) in suspected entrapment
ulna.clinicalPearl: Ulnar nerve injury at the elbow causes numbness/tingling in the little finger and weakness in finger abduction/adduction.
clinicalPearls: Ulnar nerve injury at the elbow causes numbness/tingling in the little finger and weakness in finger abduction/adduction.
Night-time elbow flexion can exacerbate cubital tunnel syndrome — consider padding or splinting

femur.brief: Thigh bone — longest and strongest bone.
femur.description: The largest long bone of the body forming the hip joint proximally and the knee joint distally. Critical for weight bearing, locomotion and muscle attachment across the pelvis and lower limb.
femur.origin: Proximal articulation with pelvis at the hip
femur.innervation: Femoral nerve (anterior compartment) and sciatic nerve contributions
functions: Supports the body's weight during standing, walking and running
Provides origin or insertion for gluteal, quadriceps, hamstring and adductor muscles
Transfers forces between pelvis and tibia through the hip and knee joints
femur.bloodSupply: Medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries, perforators from profunda femoris and artery of ligamentum teres
examTips: Check leg length, hip rotation and neurovascular status after suspected femoral fractures
Assess for shortened externally rotated leg in neck of femur fractures and perform neurovascular observations
femur.clinicalPearl: A fractured femoral neck in older adults is an orthopedic emergency — stabilise and arrange urgent orthopedics.
clinicalPearls: A fractured femoral neck in older adults is an orthopedic emergency — stabilise and arrange urgent orthopedics.
Femoral shaft fractures can cause major blood loss; monitor for hypovolaemia and fat embolism

tibia.brief: Shin bone — main weight-bearing bone of the lower leg.
tibia.description: Robust medial bone that forms the tibial plateau proximally and the medial malleolus distally, supporting body weight and anchoring key knee and ankle ligaments.
tibia.insertion: Distal tibia forms ankle joint with talus
tibia.innervation: Tibial nerve for posterior compartment muscles
tibia.action: Weight bearing and forming knee/ankle joints
functions: Supports compressive forces through the knee and ankle during stance
Serves as an insertion for patellar tendon, pes anserinus and posterior compartment muscles
Helps maintain ankle mortise alignment via the medial malleolus
tibia.bloodSupply: Nutrient artery from posterior tibial artery plus periosteal branches
examTips: Evaluate knee joint line tenderness and varus/valgus stability in tibial plateau injuries
Monitor for compartment syndrome after fractures or casting — escalating pain is an early warning
tibia.clinicalPearl: Tibial plateau fractures may impair knee stability — assess joint line tenderness and consider imaging with CT for surgical planning.
clinicalPearls: Tibial plateau fractures may impair knee stability — assess joint line tenderness and consider imaging with CT for surgical planning.
Posterior tibial fractures can compromise neurovascular supply; check distal pulses and toe movement

fibula.brief: Lateral lower-leg bone providing muscular attachment.
fibula.description: Slender lateral bone of the leg that stabilises the ankle mortise and offers extensive attachment for lateral compartment muscles while bearing minimal axial load.
fibula.innervation: Common peroneal (fibular) nerve supplies associated muscles
fibula.action: Provides lateral support and muscle attachment; minor weight bearing
functions: Stabilises the ankle mortise via the lateral malleolus
Serves as origin for peroneal muscles contributing to foot eversion
Provides attachment for lateral ligaments of the knee and ankle
fibula.bloodSupply: Fibular (peroneal) artery and branches from anterior tibial artery
examTips: Assess common peroneal nerve function (ankle dorsiflexion, sensation over first web space) after fibular neck injury
Palpate the entire fibula for tenderness in ankle sprains to exclude proximal fractures (Maisonneuve injury)
fibula.clinicalPearl: An isolated fibular head fracture may be associated with common peroneal nerve injury; examine dorsiflexion and sensation over the dorsum of the foot.
clinicalPearls: An isolated fibular head fracture may be associated with common peroneal nerve injury; examine dorsiflexion and sensation over the dorsum of the foot.
Maisonneuve fractures combine proximal fibula fracture with deltoid ligament injury—always image the entire fibula in ankle fractures

patella.brief: Kneecap — sesamoid bone in the quadriceps tendon.
patella.action: Protects knee joint and increases lever arm of quadriceps
patella.clinicalPearl: Patellar dislocation typically presents with lateral displacement and may require reduction; check extensor mechanism integrity.

pectoralis.brief: Large chest muscle involved in shoulder adduction and internal rotation.
pectoralis.description: Fan-shaped superficial chest muscle with clavicular and sternocostal heads that powerfully adduct and internally rotate the humerus while assisting with respiration when the upper limb is fixed.
pectoralis.insertion: Lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus of humerus
pectoralis.action: Adduction, internal rotation and flexion of humerus
functions: Adducts and internally rotates the humerus
Clavicular head flexes the shoulder from an extended position
Assists with deep inspiration by elevating the rib cage when arms are fixed
pectoralis.bloodSupply: Pectoral branches of thoracoacromial artery and perforators from internal thoracic artery
examTips: Test clavicular fibres by resisted shoulder flexion from 90° flexion with the arm supinated
Assess sternal fibres by resisted horizontal adduction (pressing hands together) and look for asymmetry
pectoralis.clinicalPearl: Pectoralis major tendon ruptures are seen with heavy lifting; sudden pain and weakness on adduction should raise suspicion. The 'dropped nipple sign' may be visible.
clinicalPearls: Pectoralis major tendon ruptures are seen with heavy lifting; sudden pain and weakness on adduction should raise suspicion. The 'dropped nipple sign' may be visible.
Post-mastectomy tightness can cause adduction contracture; early physiotherapy and stretching are key

pectoralis_major.brief: Large chest muscle involved in shoulder adduction and internal rotation.
pectoralis_major.description: Fan-shaped superficial chest muscle with clavicular and sternocostal heads that powerfully adduct and internally rotate the humerus while assisting with respiration when the upper limb is fixed.
pectoralis_major.insertion: Lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus of humerus
pectoralis_major.action: Adduction, internal rotation and flexion of humerus
functions: Adducts and internally rotates the humerus
Clavicular head flexes the shoulder from an extended position
Assists with deep inspiration by elevating the rib cage when arms are fixed
pectoralis_major.bloodSupply: Pectoral branches of thoracoacromial artery and perforators from internal thoracic artery
examTips: Test clavicular fibres by resisted shoulder flexion from 90° flexion with the arm supinated
Assess sternal fibres by resisted horizontal adduction (pressing hands together) and look for asymmetry
pectoralis_major.clinicalPearl: Pectoralis major tendon ruptures are seen with heavy lifting; sudden pain and weakness on adduction should raise suspicion. The 'dropped nipple sign' may be visible.
clinicalPearls: Pectoralis major tendon ruptures are seen with heavy lifting; sudden pain and weakness on adduction should raise suspicion. The 'dropped nipple sign' may be visible.
Post-mastectomy tightness can cause adduction contracture; early physiotherapy and stretching are key

pectoralis_minor.brief: Small chest muscle deep to pectoralis major.
pectoralis_minor.action: Stabilizes scapula by drawing it forward and downward
pectoralis_minor.clinicalPearl: Can compress brachial plexus and subclavian vessels causing thoracic outlet syndrome symptoms.

rotator_cuff.brief: Group of four muscles stabilizing the shoulder joint (SITS).
rotator_cuff.origin: Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Teres minor from scapula; Subscapularis from subscapular fossa
rotator_cuff.insertion: All insert on humerus forming the rotator cuff around glenohumeral joint
rotator_cuff.innervation: Suprascapular nerve (supra/infraspinatus), axillary nerve (teres minor), subscapular nerves
rotator_cuff.action: Stabilize humeral head in glenoid fossa; initiate abduction, external/internal rotation
rotator_cuff.clinicalPearl: Supraspinatus is most commonly torn. Test with 'empty can test' (painful arc 60-120°). MRI is gold standard for diagnosis. Chronic tears may lead to arthropathy.

masseter.brief: Powerful muscle of mastication elevating the jaw.
masseter.insertion: Lateral surface of mandibular ramus and angle
masseter.innervation: Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V3)
masseter.clinicalPearl: Masseter hypertrophy can cause 'square jaw' appearance. Assess for bruxism (teeth grinding). Trismus indicates inflammation or tetanus.

sternocleidomastoid.brief: Superficial neck muscle for head rotation and flexion.
sternocleidomastoid.description: Paired muscle with sternal and clavicular heads that flex the neck, rotate the head and form a key landmark for cervical structures such as the carotid sheath.
sternocleidomastoid.origin: Manubrium of sternum and medial clavicle
sternocleidomastoid.insertion: Mastoid process of temporal bone and lateral superior nuchal line
sternocleidomastoid.innervation: Spinal accessory nerve (motor) with C2-C3 proprioceptive fibres
sternocleidomastoid.action: Unilateral lateral flexion with contralateral rotation; bilateral neck flexion
functions: Turns the chin to the opposite side while tilting the head toward the same shoulder
Flexes the neck when both sides contract
Assists in forced inspiration by elevating the sternum when the neck is fixed
examTips: Ask the patient to rotate the head against resistance to assess spinal accessory nerve strength
Palpate anterior to the muscle for carotid pulse while the patient relaxes to avoid syncope
sternocleidomastoid.clinicalPearl: Accessory nerve palsy results in sternocleidomastoid and trapezius weakness; assess after posterior triangle surgery.
clinicalPearls: Congenital muscular torticollis causes head tilt toward the affected side with chin rotation away — early physiotherapy prevents contractures
Accessory nerve palsy results in SCM and trapezius weakness; evaluate following posterior triangle surgery

deltoid.description: Triangular superficial shoulder muscle with anterior, middle and posterior fibres that provide the primary abduction force and dynamic stability to the glenohumeral joint.
deltoid.origin: Lateral third of clavicle, acromion and spine of scapula
deltoid.action: Abduction, flexion, extension and rotation of the arm depending on fibres
functions: Middle fibres abduct the arm beyond the first 15° (initiated by supraspinatus)
Anterior fibres flex and internally rotate the shoulder
Posterior fibres extend and externally rotate the shoulder
deltoid.bloodSupply: Posterior circumflex humeral artery and deltoid branch of thoracoacromial artery
examTips: Test abduction from 15–90° against resistance to isolate deltoid function
Assess regimental badge sensation and shoulder contour after dislocation to screen axillary nerve
deltoid.clinicalPearl: Axillary nerve injury from shoulder dislocation causes deltoid weakness and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area).
clinicalPearls: Axillary nerve injury from shoulder dislocation causes deltoid weakness and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area).
Deltoid intramuscular injections should be administered 2–3 fingerbreadths below the acromion to avoid nerve injury

biceps.brief: Anterior arm muscle for elbow flexion and supination.
biceps.description: Two-headed anterior arm muscle spanning the shoulder and elbow that flexes the elbow and supinates the forearm while stabilising the glenohumeral joint.
biceps.origin: Long head from supraglenoid tubercle; short head from coracoid process
functions: Primary supinator of the forearm when the elbow is flexed
Flexes the elbow, particularly in supinated positions
Long head assists shoulder flexion and stabilises the humeral head
examTips: Perform the hook test or squeeze test to evaluate distal biceps tendon integrity
Check supination strength with the elbow flexed to 90° to isolate the biceps
biceps.clinicalPearl: Biceps tendon rupture may present with a 'Popeye' deformity and weakness of supination.
clinicalPearls: Biceps tendon rupture may present with a 'Popeye' deformity and weakness of supination.
Repeated steroid injections around the tendon increase rupture risk — use ultrasound guidance when possible

biceps_brachii.brief: Anterior arm muscle for elbow flexion and supination.
biceps_brachii.description: Two-headed anterior arm muscle spanning the shoulder and elbow that flexes the elbow and supinates the forearm while stabilising the glenohumeral joint.
biceps_brachii.origin: Long head from supraglenoid tubercle; short head from coracoid process
functions: Primary supinator of the forearm when the elbow is flexed
Flexes the elbow, particularly in supinated positions
Long head assists shoulder flexion and stabilises the humeral head
examTips: Perform the hook test or squeeze test to evaluate distal biceps tendon integrity
Check supination strength with the elbow flexed to 90° to isolate the biceps
biceps_brachii.clinicalPearl: Biceps tendon rupture may present with a 'Popeye' deformity and weakness of supination.
clinicalPearls: Biceps tendon rupture may present with a 'Popeye' deformity and weakness of supination.
Repeated steroid injections around the tendon increase rupture risk — use ultrasound guidance when possible

quadriceps.brief: Anterior thigh muscle group for knee extension.
quadriceps.description: Four-muscle group comprising rectus femoris, vastus medialis, vastus lateralis and vastus intermedius that extends the knee and stabilises the patella.
quadriceps.origin: Various heads from femur and iliac spine
quadriceps.insertion: Patella via quadriceps tendon to tibial tuberosity
quadriceps.action: Knee extension and hip flexion (rectus femoris)
functions: Extend the knee joint to enable standing, walking and jumping
Rectus femoris also flexes the hip
Vastus medialis obliquus stabilises the patella medially
quadriceps.bloodSupply: Lateral circumflex femoral and profunda femoris branches
examTips: Test active straight-leg raise to assess quadriceps tendon integrity
Elicit patellar tendon reflex (L3-L4) to screen femoral nerve function
quadriceps.clinicalPearl: Quadriceps tendon rupture results in inability to actively extend the knee; examine for suprapatellar gap.
clinicalPearls: Quadriceps tendon rupture results in inability to actively extend the knee; examine for suprapatellar gap.
Vastus medialis weakness can lead to patellofemoral pain—strengthen with terminal knee extension exercises

gastrocnemius.description: Superficial calf muscle with medial and lateral heads that crosses the knee and ankle to generate powerful plantarflexion for propulsion.
gastrocnemius.action: Plantarflexion of the foot and knee flexion
functions: Provides propulsive force during toe-off in gait
Assists with knee flexion when the foot is dorsiflexed
Acts with soleus as part of the triceps surae to maintain posture
gastrocnemius.bloodSupply: Sural branches of the popliteal artery
examTips: Perform the Thompson squeeze test to rule out Achilles rupture
Assess single-leg heel raises for calf strength
gastrocnemius.clinicalPearl: Achilles tendon rupture commonly presents with a snapping sensation and difficulty with push-off; Thompson test can help diagnosis.
clinicalPearls: Achilles tendon rupture commonly presents with a snapping sensation and difficulty with push-off; Thompson test can help diagnosis.
Medial head tears cause sudden calf pain in tennis players—known as 'tennis leg'

triceps.brief: Posterior arm muscle for elbow extension.
triceps.description: Three-headed muscle forming the posterior compartment of the arm that extends the elbow and contributes to shoulder extension and adduction via its long head.
triceps.origin: Long head from infraglenoid tubercle; lateral and medial heads from humerus
triceps.action: Elbow extension and shoulder adduction (long head)
functions: Extends the elbow to straighten the forearm
Long head assists with shoulder extension and adduction
Provides dynamic stability to the elbow joint during pushing movements
examTips: Elicit the triceps reflex (C7-C8) to evaluate radial nerve integrity
Test resisted elbow extension with the shoulder abducted to 90° to isolate triceps
triceps.clinicalPearl: Radial nerve palsy causes wrist drop and inability to extend the elbow or wrist.
clinicalPearls: Radial nerve palsy causes wrist drop and inability to extend the elbow or wrist.
Posterior elbow dislocations can stretch the triceps and radial nerve—reassess after reduction

triceps_brachii.brief: Posterior arm muscle for elbow extension.
triceps_brachii.description: Three-headed muscle forming the posterior compartment of the arm that extends the elbow and contributes to shoulder extension and adduction via its long head.
triceps_brachii.origin: Long head from infraglenoid tubercle; lateral and medial heads from humerus
triceps_brachii.action: Elbow extension and shoulder adduction (long head)
functions: Extends the elbow to straighten the forearm
Long head assists with shoulder extension and adduction
Provides dynamic stability to the elbow joint during pushing movements
examTips: Elicit the triceps reflex (C7-C8) to evaluate radial nerve integrity
Test resisted elbow extension with the shoulder abducted to 90° to isolate triceps
triceps_brachii.clinicalPearl: Radial nerve palsy causes wrist drop and inability to extend the elbow or wrist.
clinicalPearls: Radial nerve palsy causes wrist drop and inability to extend the elbow or wrist.
Posterior elbow dislocations can stretch the triceps and radial nerve—reassess after reduction

latissimus_dorsi.brief: Large back muscle for shoulder adduction and extension.
latissimus_dorsi.description: Broad superficial muscle covering the lower back, inserting into the humerus to adduct, extend and internally rotate the shoulder while assisting with climbing and coughing.
latissimus_dorsi.origin: Lower thoracic and lumbar vertebrae, sacrum, iliac crest
latissimus_dorsi.action: Adduction, extension, and internal rotation of shoulder
functions: Powerfully adducts and extends the humerus from a flexed position
Depresses the scapula to aid in crutch walking or transfers
Assists with forced expiration and coughing by compressing the thorax
examTips: Test shoulder adduction against resistance with the arm elevated
Palpate the posterior axillary fold during resisted extension to ensure activation
latissimus_dorsi.clinicalPearl: Used in breast reconstruction surgery as a myocutaneous flap. Test by having patient cough.
clinicalPearls: Used in breast reconstruction surgery as a myocutaneous flap. Test by having patient cough.
Thoracodorsal nerve damage during axillary dissection weakens shoulder adduction and extension

trapezius.brief: Large superficial back muscle for scapular movement.
trapezius.description: Superficial kite-shaped muscle spanning the upper back and neck with upper, middle and lower fibres coordinating scapular elevation, retraction and upward rotation.
trapezius.origin: Occipital bone, nuchal ligament, spinous processes C7-T12
trapezius.insertion: Lateral clavicle, acromion, spine of scapula
functions: Upper fibres elevate and upwardly rotate the scapula
Middle fibres retract the scapula
Lower fibres depress and assist upward rotation of the scapula
trapezius.bloodSupply: Superficial branch of transverse cervical artery and dorsal scapular artery
examTips: Assess shrug strength against resistance to evaluate spinal accessory nerve integrity
Observe scapular movement during arm abduction for dyskinesis indicating trapezius weakness
trapezius.clinicalPearl: Spinal accessory nerve injury causes shoulder droop and inability to shrug. Can occur iatrogenically during neck surgery.
clinicalPearls: Spinal accessory nerve injury causes shoulder droop and inability to shrug. Can occur iatrogenically during neck surgery.
Chronic trapezius overuse contributes to tension headaches—encourage posture correction and stretching

rectus_abdominis.description: Paired strap muscle segmented by tendinous intersections that flexes the trunk, stabilises the pelvis and maintains intra-abdominal pressure.
rectus_abdominis.action: Trunk flexion and compression of abdominal contents
functions: Flexes the lumbar spine and assists with posterior pelvic tilt
Supports abdominal viscera and increases intra-abdominal pressure during cough or defecation
Stabilises the pelvis during gait and transfers load between thorax and lower limbs
examTips: Inspect for diastasis recti when patient performs a partial sit-up
Palpate along the linea alba for hernia defects while the patient strains
rectus_abdominis.clinicalPearl: Diastasis recti is separation of the rectus abdominis, common in pregnancy. Grey Turner's sign (flank bruising) suggests retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
clinicalPearls: Diastasis recti is separation of the rectus abdominis, common in pregnancy. Grey Turner's sign (flank bruising) suggests retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
Abdominal trauma with ecchymosis over the umbilicus (Cullen sign) warrants evaluation for internal bleeding

external_oblique.brief: Lateral abdominal muscle for trunk rotation.
external_oblique.description: Superficial abdominal muscle forming the anterolateral abdominal wall and inguinal ligament, working with contralateral internal oblique to rotate the trunk and support abdominal contents.
external_oblique.action: Trunk flexion, lateral bending, and contralateral rotation
functions: Rotates the trunk to the opposite side when acting with contralateral internal oblique
Compresses abdominal contents and assists with forced expiration
Contributes to formation of inguinal ligament and superficial inguinal ring
external_oblique.bloodSupply: Lower intercostal and deep circumflex iliac arteries
examTips: Assess trunk rotation strength while the patient performs a sit-up touching the contralateral knee
Palpate above the inguinal ligament to detect direct or indirect hernias during cough impulse
external_oblique.clinicalPearl: Forms the inguinal ligament and superficial inguinal ring. Important in inguinal hernia anatomy.
clinicalPearls: Forms the inguinal ligament and superficial inguinal ring. Important in inguinal hernia anatomy.
Oblique muscle tears in athletes cause flank pain—rehabilitation focuses on rotational core strength

gluteus_maximus.brief: Largest buttock muscle for hip extension.
gluteus_maximus.description: Powerful hip extensor activated during rising, climbing and sprinting; also provides pelvic stability via its attachment to the iliotibial tract.
gluteus_maximus.insertion: Iliotibial tract and gluteal tuberosity of femur
gluteus_maximus.action: Hip extension, lateral rotation, and stabilization
functions: Extends the hip from a flexed position (e.g., sit-to-stand, stair climbing)
Laterally rotates and abducts the thigh
Stabilises the trunk and pelvis via iliotibial tract tension
examTips: Assess hip extension strength with patient prone, knee flexed
Observe gait for difficulty climbing or rising indicative of gluteal weakness
gluteus_maximus.clinicalPearl: Trendelenburg gait (hip drop on contralateral side) indicates superior gluteal nerve injury affecting gluteus medius/minimus, not maximus.
clinicalPearls: Trendelenburg gait (hip drop on contralateral side) indicates superior gluteal nerve injury affecting gluteus medius/minimus, not maximus.
Posterior hip dislocations risk inferior gluteal nerve injury—check hip extension power after reduction

hamstrings.brief: Posterior thigh muscle group for knee flexion.
hamstrings.description: Three-muscle group (biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus) spanning hip and knee to extend the hip and flex the knee.
functions: Extend the hip during propulsion and stance
Flex the knee and assist in tibial rotation
Stabilise the pelvis by countering hip flexion
examTips: Assess straight-leg raise flexibility and compare bilaterally
Test resisted knee flexion with the hip extended to isolate hamstrings
hamstrings.clinicalPearl: Hamstring strains are common in sprinting. Proximal avulsion injuries can occur with violent hip flexion during knee extension.
clinicalPearls: Hamstring strains are common in sprinting. Proximal avulsion injuries can occur with violent hip flexion during knee extension.
Chronic tendinopathy at the ischial tuberosity causes sitting pain—rehab emphasises eccentric loading

soleus.description: Broad, fatigue-resistant muscle deep to gastrocnemius that plantarflexes the ankle and pumps venous blood back toward the heart.
soleus.action: Plantarflexion of foot (especially when knee is flexed)
functions: Maintains upright posture by preventing forward sway
Provides sustained plantarflexion during standing and walking
Acts as a venous pump aiding return circulation
examTips: Test endurance with repetitive heel raises while knee is slightly flexed
Palpate deep to gastrocnemius for tenderness in overuse injuries
soleus.clinicalPearl: Deep to gastrocnemius, forms the triceps surae. Important in venous return ('peripheral heart').
clinicalPearls: Deep to gastrocnemius, forms the triceps surae. Important in venous return ('peripheral heart').
Soleus strains cause deep calf aching with prolonged standing—contrast with gastrocnemius tears

serratus_anterior.brief: Lateral chest muscle that protracts the scapula.
serratus_anterior.description: Saw-toothed muscle on the lateral thoracic wall that anchors the scapula to the rib cage and enables overhead reach by producing scapular protraction and upward rotation.
functions: Protracts and stabilises the scapula against the thoracic wall
Assists trapezius in upward rotation for full shoulder abduction
Provides a platform for powerful pushing movements
examTips: Ask the patient to push against a wall to observe for scapular winging
Palpate along the ribs during resisted protraction to identify trigger points in athletes
serratus_anterior.clinicalPearl: Long thoracic nerve injury causes winged scapula. Test by having patient push against wall.
clinicalPearls: Long thoracic nerve injury causes winged scapula. Test by having patient push against wall.
Serratus anterior strengthening (push-up plus) is essential in scapular dyskinesis rehabilitation

tibialis_anterior.brief: Anterior lower leg muscle for dorsiflexion.
tibialis_anterior.description: Primary dorsiflexor of the ankle located in the anterior compartment of the leg; also inverts the foot and supports the medial arch during gait.
tibialis_anterior.insertion: Medial cuneiform and first metatarsal base
functions: Dorsiflexes the ankle during swing phase to prevent toe drag
Controls foot placement during heel strike
Assists in maintaining medial longitudinal arch
examTips: Test ankle dorsiflexion strength against resistance and assess heel-walking
Look for shin splints tenderness along the tibial border in overuse injuries
tibialis_anterior.clinicalPearl: Foot drop indicates deep peroneal nerve or L5 nerve root injury. Test by asking patient to walk on heels.
clinicalPearls: Foot drop indicates deep peroneal nerve or L5 nerve root injury. Test by asking patient to walk on heels.
Chronic compartment syndrome presents with anterior leg pain and foot drop during exertion

brachioradialis.clinicalPearl: Tests radial nerve C5-C6 function. Diminished brachioradialis reflex suggests C6 radiculopathy.

sartorius.brief: Longest muscle in body, crosses hip and knee.
sartorius.action: Hip flexion, abduction, lateral rotation; knee flexion
sartorius.clinicalPearl: Crosses both hip and knee joints. Forms part of pes anserinus with gracilis and semitendinosus.

iliopsoas.brief: Primary hip flexor muscle (iliacus + psoas major).
iliopsoas.clinicalPearl: Psoas abscess causes hip flexion contracture and fever. Positive psoas sign suggests appendicitis.

adductors.brief: Medial thigh muscle group for hip adduction.
adductors.clinicalPearl: Adductor strains common in athletes. Obturator nerve injury causes weakness in hip adduction.

erector_spinae.brief: Deep back muscle group for spine extension.
erector_spinae.description: Longitudinal column of iliocostalis, longissimus and spinalis muscles that extend, laterally flex and stabilise the vertebral column.
erector_spinae.action: Spine extension, lateral bending, and postural control
functions: Extend the spine when both sides contract
Laterally flex the spine when contracting unilaterally
Maintain upright posture and control spinal flexion eccentrically
erector_spinae.bloodSupply: Dorsal branches of intercostal and lumbar arteries
examTips: Palpate paraspinal tone with patient prone to assess spasm in low back pain
Test endurance with the Sorensen test to identify core weakness
erector_spinae.clinicalPearl: Paraspinal muscle spasm common in low back pain. Includes iliocostalis, longissimus, and spinalis.
clinicalPearls: Paraspinal muscle spasm common in low back pain. Includes iliocostalis, longissimus, and spinalis.
Strengthening erector spinae reduces recurrent lumbar strain—incorporate extension exercises

rhomboids.description: Pair of muscles deep to trapezius that retract and downwardly rotate the scapula, securing it against the thoracic wall.
rhomboids.origin: Nuchal ligament and spinous processes C7-T5
functions: Pull the scapula medially and downward
Stabilise the medial border during arm movements
Work with serratus anterior to maintain scapulothoracic rhythm
examTips: Test scapular retraction strength with hands on hips and elbows pushed backward
Palpate medial border for prominence indicating rhomboid weakness
rhomboids.clinicalPearl: Dorsal scapular nerve palsy leads to lateral scapular winging and difficulty retracting the scapula.
clinicalPearls: Dorsal scapular nerve palsy leads to lateral scapular winging and difficulty retracting the scapula
Desk workers often develop rhomboid trigger points from prolonged protraction—encourage posture exercises

Scapula.brief: Flat triangular bone on the posterior thorax.
Scapula.origin: Spine, acromion, and coracoid process provide attachment sites
Scapula.insertion: Glenoid fossa articulates with humeral head
Scapula.innervation: Dorsal scapular nerve, suprascapular nerve, axillary nerve
Scapula.action: Provides attachment for shoulder muscles, enables arm movement
Scapula.clinicalPearl: Scapular winging indicates serratus anterior weakness (long thoracic nerve injury). Check by having patient push against a wall.

ClavicleLeft.brief: S-shaped bone connecting the shoulder to the axial skeleton.
ClavicleLeft.origin: Medial end articulates with manubrium of sternum
ClavicleLeft.insertion: Lateral end articulates with acromion of scapula
ClavicleLeft.action: Strut connecting upper limb to trunk, protects neurovascular bundle
ClavicleLeft.clinicalPearl: Most commonly fractured bone in children. Falls on outstretched hand (FOOSH) cause fractures typically at the middle third. Check for tenting of skin and neurovascular compromise.

ClavicleRight.brief: S-shaped bone connecting the shoulder to the axial skeleton.
ClavicleRight.origin: Medial end articulates with manubrium of sternum
ClavicleRight.insertion: Lateral end articulates with acromion of scapula
ClavicleRight.action: Strut connecting upper limb to trunk, protects neurovascular bundle
ClavicleRight.clinicalPearl: Most commonly fractured bone in children. Falls on outstretched hand (FOOSH) cause fractures typically at the middle third. Check for tenting of skin and neurovascular compromise.

Humerus.origin: Proximal articulations with the scapula (glenohumeral joint)
Humerus.insertion: Distally with radius and ulna at the elbow
Humerus.action: Upper limb movement and force transmission
Humerus.clinicalPearl: Proximal humeral fractures are common in older adults after a fall; check axillary nerve function (shoulder abduction) and vascular status.

HumerusLeft.origin: Proximal articulations with the scapula (glenohumeral joint)
HumerusLeft.insertion: Distally with radius and ulna at the elbow
HumerusLeft.action: Upper limb movement and force transmission
HumerusLeft.clinicalPearl: Proximal humeral fractures are common in older adults after a fall; check axillary nerve function (shoulder abduction) and vascular status.

HumerusRight.origin: Proximal articulations with the scapula (glenohumeral joint)
HumerusRight.insertion: Distally with radius and ulna at the elbow
HumerusRight.action: Upper limb movement and force transmission
HumerusRight.clinicalPearl: Proximal humeral fractures are common in older adults after a fall; check axillary nerve function (shoulder abduction) and vascular status.

Radius.origin: Radial head articulates with capitulum of humerus
Radius.insertion: Distal radius articulates with scaphoid and lunate at wrist
Radius.clinicalPearl: Distal radius (Colles') fractures common in FOOSH injuries. Check for median nerve injury causing carpal tunnel symptoms.

RadiusLeft.origin: Radial head articulates with capitulum of humerus
RadiusLeft.insertion: Distal radius articulates with scaphoid and lunate at wrist
RadiusLeft.clinicalPearl: Distal radius (Colles') fractures common in FOOSH injuries. Check for median nerve injury causing carpal tunnel symptoms.

RadiusRight.origin: Radial head articulates with capitulum of humerus
RadiusRight.insertion: Distal radius articulates with scaphoid and lunate at wrist
RadiusRight.clinicalPearl: Distal radius (Colles') fractures common in FOOSH injuries. Check for median nerve injury causing carpal tunnel symptoms.

Ulna.brief: Medial forearm bone providing elbow stability.
Ulna.origin: Olecranon articulates with trochlea of humerus
Ulna.insertion: Distal ulna with triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC)
Ulna.clinicalPearl: Monteggia fracture: proximal ulna fracture with radial head dislocation. Galeazzi fracture: distal radius with distal radioulnar joint injury.

UlnaLeft.brief: Medial forearm bone providing elbow stability.
UlnaLeft.origin: Olecranon articulates with trochlea of humerus
UlnaLeft.insertion: Distal ulna with triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC)
UlnaLeft.clinicalPearl: Monteggia fracture: proximal ulna fracture with radial head dislocation. Galeazzi fracture: distal radius with distal radioulnar joint injury.

UlnaRight.brief: Medial forearm bone providing elbow stability.
UlnaRight.origin: Olecranon articulates with trochlea of humerus
UlnaRight.insertion: Distal ulna with triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC)
UlnaRight.clinicalPearl: Monteggia fracture: proximal ulna fracture with radial head dislocation. Galeazzi fracture: distal radius with distal radioulnar joint injury.

Femur.brief: Longest and strongest bone in the body (thigh bone).
Femur.description: Primary load-bearing bone of the thigh forming the hip and knee joints. Transfers ground reaction forces to the pelvis and anchors powerful locomotor muscles.
Femur.origin: Femoral head articulates with acetabulum at hip
Femur.insertion: Distal femoral condyles articulate with tibia at knee
Femur.innervation: Femoral nerve and sciatic nerve supply surrounding muscles
Femur.action: Weight bearing, locomotion, and lower limb force transmission
functions: Supports body weight during stance and gait
Serves as the origin/insertion for gluteals, quadriceps, hamstrings and adductors
Facilitates hip and knee leverage for propulsion
Femur.bloodSupply: Medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries with branches from profunda femoris
examTips: Assess for leg shortening and external rotation in suspected neck of femur fractures
Document distal pulses and motor/sensory function to exclude femoral neurovascular injury
Femur.clinicalPearl: Femoral neck fractures can disrupt blood supply to femoral head, risking avascular necrosis. Check for shortened, externally rotated leg.
clinicalPearls: Femoral neck fractures can disrupt blood supply to femoral head, risking avascular necrosis. Check for shortened, externally rotated leg.
Femoral shaft fractures may be associated with fat embolism syndrome—monitor for respiratory distress and petechiae

FemurLeft.brief: Longest and strongest bone in the body (thigh bone).
FemurLeft.description: Primary load-bearing bone of the thigh forming the hip and knee joints. Transfers ground reaction forces to the pelvis and anchors powerful locomotor muscles.
FemurLeft.origin: Femoral head articulates with acetabulum at hip
FemurLeft.insertion: Distal femoral condyles articulate with tibia at knee
FemurLeft.innervation: Femoral nerve and sciatic nerve supply surrounding muscles
FemurLeft.action: Weight bearing, locomotion, and lower limb force transmission
functions: Supports body weight during stance and gait
Serves as the origin/insertion for gluteals, quadriceps, hamstrings and adductors
Facilitates hip and knee leverage for propulsion
FemurLeft.bloodSupply: Medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries with branches from profunda femoris
examTips: Assess for leg shortening and external rotation in suspected neck of femur fractures
Document distal pulses and motor/sensory function to exclude femoral neurovascular injury
FemurLeft.clinicalPearl: Femoral neck fractures can disrupt blood supply to femoral head, risking avascular necrosis. Check for shortened, externally rotated leg.
clinicalPearls: Femoral neck fractures can disrupt blood supply to femoral head, risking avascular necrosis. Check for shortened, externally rotated leg.
Femoral shaft fractures may be associated with fat embolism syndrome—monitor for respiratory distress and petechiae

FemurRight.brief: Longest and strongest bone in the body (thigh bone).
FemurRight.description: Primary load-bearing bone of the thigh forming the hip and knee joints. Transfers ground reaction forces to the pelvis and anchors powerful locomotor muscles.
FemurRight.origin: Femoral head articulates with acetabulum at hip
FemurRight.insertion: Distal femoral condyles articulate with tibia at knee
FemurRight.innervation: Femoral nerve and sciatic nerve supply surrounding muscles
FemurRight.action: Weight bearing, locomotion, and lower limb force transmission
functions: Supports body weight during stance and gait
Serves as the origin/insertion for gluteals, quadriceps, hamstrings and adductors
Facilitates hip and knee leverage for propulsion
FemurRight.bloodSupply: Medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries with branches from profunda femoris
examTips: Assess for leg shortening and external rotation in suspected neck of femur fractures
Document distal pulses and motor/sensory function to exclude femoral neurovascular injury
FemurRight.clinicalPearl: Femoral neck fractures can disrupt blood supply to femoral head, risking avascular necrosis. Check for shortened, externally rotated leg.
clinicalPearls: Femoral neck fractures can disrupt blood supply to femoral head, risking avascular necrosis. Check for shortened, externally rotated leg.
Femoral shaft fractures may be associated with fat embolism syndrome—monitor for respiratory distress and petechiae

Tibia.brief: Larger medial shin bone bearing most of lower leg weight.
Tibia.description: Primary weight-bearing bone of the leg forming the knee joint proximally and the ankle mortise distally. Provides attachment for patellar tendon and soleus and supports gait stability.
Tibia.origin: Tibial plateau articulates with femoral condyles
Tibia.innervation: Tibial nerve and common peroneal nerve branches
functions: Supports body weight through the knee and ankle
Provides insertion for quadriceps via patellar tendon and posterior leg muscles
Maintains ankle mortise stability with medial malleolus
Tibia.bloodSupply: Anterior and posterior tibial arteries and nutrient branches
examTips: Palpate the tibial crest and malleoli for tenderness or displacement after injury
Monitor compartments closely for rising pain, pain on passive stretch and neurovascular compromise
Tibia.clinicalPearl: Tibial shaft fractures may cause compartment syndrome. Monitor for 5 P's: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, Paralysis.
clinicalPearls: Tibial shaft fractures may cause compartment syndrome. Monitor for 5 P's: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, Paralysis.
Stress fractures are common in runners — look for focal tibial tenderness and consider MRI if X-ray negative

TibiaLeft.brief: Larger medial shin bone bearing most of lower leg weight.
TibiaLeft.description: Primary weight-bearing bone of the leg forming the knee joint proximally and the ankle mortise distally. Provides attachment for patellar tendon and soleus and supports gait stability.
TibiaLeft.origin: Tibial plateau articulates with femoral condyles
TibiaLeft.innervation: Tibial nerve and common peroneal nerve branches
functions: Supports body weight through the knee and ankle
Provides insertion for quadriceps via patellar tendon and posterior leg muscles
Maintains ankle mortise stability with medial malleolus
TibiaLeft.bloodSupply: Anterior and posterior tibial arteries and nutrient branches
examTips: Palpate the tibial crest and malleoli for tenderness or displacement after injury
Monitor compartments closely for rising pain, pain on passive stretch and neurovascular compromise
TibiaLeft.clinicalPearl: Tibial shaft fractures may cause compartment syndrome. Monitor for 5 P's: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, Paralysis.
clinicalPearls: Tibial shaft fractures may cause compartment syndrome. Monitor for 5 P's: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, Paralysis.
Stress fractures are common in runners — look for focal tibial tenderness and consider MRI if X-ray negative

TibiaRight.brief: Larger medial shin bone bearing most of lower leg weight.
TibiaRight.description: Primary weight-bearing bone of the leg forming the knee joint proximally and the ankle mortise distally. Provides attachment for patellar tendon and soleus and supports gait stability.
TibiaRight.origin: Tibial plateau articulates with femoral condyles
TibiaRight.innervation: Tibial nerve and common peroneal nerve branches
functions: Supports body weight through the knee and ankle
Provides insertion for quadriceps via patellar tendon and posterior leg muscles
Maintains ankle mortise stability with medial malleolus
TibiaRight.bloodSupply: Anterior and posterior tibial arteries and nutrient branches
examTips: Palpate the tibial crest and malleoli for tenderness or displacement after injury
Monitor compartments closely for rising pain, pain on passive stretch and neurovascular compromise
TibiaRight.clinicalPearl: Tibial shaft fractures may cause compartment syndrome. Monitor for 5 P's: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, Paralysis.
clinicalPearls: Tibial shaft fractures may cause compartment syndrome. Monitor for 5 P's: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, Paralysis.
Stress fractures are common in runners — look for focal tibial tenderness and consider MRI if X-ray negative

Fibula.brief: Lateral, smaller bone of the lower leg.
Fibula.origin: Fibular head articulates with tibia proximally
Fibula.clinicalPearl: Maisonneuve fracture: proximal fibula fracture with ankle injury. Peroneal nerve injury causes foot drop.

FibulaLeft.brief: Lateral, smaller bone of the lower leg.
FibulaLeft.origin: Fibular head articulates with tibia proximally
FibulaLeft.clinicalPearl: Maisonneuve fracture: proximal fibula fracture with ankle injury. Peroneal nerve injury causes foot drop.

FibulaRight.brief: Lateral, smaller bone of the lower leg.
FibulaRight.origin: Fibular head articulates with tibia proximally
FibulaRight.clinicalPearl: Maisonneuve fracture: proximal fibula fracture with ankle injury. Peroneal nerve injury causes foot drop.

Sacrum.brief: Triangular bone at base of spine, fused sacral vertebrae.
Sacrum.origin: Fusion of 5 sacral vertebrae during development
Sacrum.insertion: Articulates with ilium (sacroiliac joint) and coccyx
Sacrum.action: Connects spine to pelvis, transmits weight to lower limbs
Sacrum.clinicalPearl: Sacral fractures often occur with pelvic ring injuries. Check for neurologic deficits affecting bowel/bladder function.

Coccyx.brief: Terminal portion of vertebral column, 3-5 fused vertebrae.
Coccyx.action: Attachment point for pelvic floor muscles
Coccyx.clinicalPearl: Coccydynia (tailbone pain) common after falls onto buttocks. Most cases managed conservatively.

CervicalVertebrae.brief: Seven neck vertebrae supporting the head and enabling neck motion.
CervicalVertebrae.origin: Forms from sclerotomes during embryonic development
CervicalVertebrae.insertion: Stack from skull (atlas) to thoracic spine
CervicalVertebrae.action: Head support, neck flexion/extension/rotation, spinal cord protection
CervicalVertebrae.clinicalPearl: C-spine injury risk with trauma. Canadian C-Spine Rules help guide imaging. Remember: C3,4,5 keeps the diaphragm alive.

ThoracicVertebrae.brief: Twelve mid-back vertebrae articulating with ribs.
ThoracicVertebrae.insertion: Connect cervical to lumbar spine, articulate with ribs
ThoracicVertebrae.action: Rib cage support, spinal stability, protect thoracic organs
ThoracicVertebrae.clinicalPearl: Thoracic spine fractures often stable due to rib cage support. Compression fractures common in osteoporosis.

LumbarVertebrae.brief: Five lower back vertebrae bearing most body weight.
LumbarVertebrae.action: Weight bearing, trunk flexion/extension, spinal cord protection
LumbarVertebrae.clinicalPearl: L4-L5 and L5-S1 most common sites for disc herniation. Straight leg raise tests nerve root tension.

Sternum.brief: Midline breastbone connecting the rib cage.
Sternum.origin: Manubrium, body, xiphoid process (components of the sternum)
Sternum.action: Central anchor for ribs and thoracic muscles
Sternum.clinicalPearl: Sternal fractures commonly result from high-energy anterior chest trauma; evaluate for cardiac contusion if suspected.

Ribs.brief: Form the rib cage to protect thoracic organs.
Ribs.insertion: Anteriorly to the sternum (true ribs) or via costal cartilage (false ribs)
Ribs.innervation: Intercostal nerves (ventral rami of thoracic spinal nerves)
Ribs.action: Protection of thoracic organs and assistance with respiration
Ribs.clinicalPearl: Flail chest (multiple adjacent rib fractures) can cause paradoxical chest wall motion; consider analgesia and respiratory support.

Pelvis.brief: Bony ring formed by sacrum and two hip bones (ilium, ischium, pubis).
Pelvis.origin: Fusion of ilium, ischium, and pubis bones
Pelvis.insertion: Articulates with sacrum and femoral heads
Pelvis.action: Weight transmission from spine to legs, protects pelvic organs
Pelvis.clinicalPearl: Pelvic fractures can be life-threatening due to massive hemorrhage. Use pelvic binder for unstable injuries.
